item.title: Deploy Cloud Run Services, Schedule invocations Using Cloud Scheduler
item.description:
TL;DR: This post is about Cloud Run and Scheduling a call of a Cloud Run service with Cloud Scheduler. Precisely we use Cloud Run to deploy a stateless birthday reminder app and use Cloud Scheduler to call the deployed service API.

In the previous post, I deployed a simple birthday reminder app on Google Cloud Functions and scheduled a cron job using Cloud Scheduler to invoke the app every day. Upon invocation, the app checks for birthdays and sends out an SMS to your configured phone number if there is at least one birthday that day. It works fine. Today, I am going to package up the birthday app in a container image using Docker, push it to Google Container Registry and then deploy it to Cloud Run.

1. What is Docker

Docker is a platform that allows you to package up your application and its dependencies in a container image. Essentially it allows you to build, share and run container images.

2. What is a container image

It's the image of a container. It's built from a file called Dockerfile, which is a script-like file that contains a series of commands which are to be executed successively by docker to create a container image.

A container image is your app bundled up together with all the dependencies that are necessary to make it run. You can package 'anything' in a container image. Any runtime, any binary, any library. Instead of container image, often we just say image.

3. What is a container

A container is a running image. Basically when your app packaged up in a container image is spun up (executed), it's called container.

4. What is Container Registry

Container Registry is Google's repository for container images. Put simply, it's like the GitHub of container images, however it's not public. The largest public repository for container images is Docker Hub. With Google Container Registry, you can manage your Docker images, perform vulnerability analysis, and because it's a GCP service, you decide who can access what with fine-grained access control using IAM policies.

5. What is Cloud Run

Cloud Run is the Cloud Functions for containers. It's a fully managed serverless compute solution that enables you to run any stateless application. It is really flexible, since you can code up an app using any runtime and any library, package it up in a container image and run it on Cloud Run. It's not limited to a couple of runtimes as it is the case with Cloud Functions. But similar to Cloud Functions, Cloud Run can scale down to zero when it's not being used, thereby costing nothing. It can also scale up to handle increasing user requests.

6. The code

Let's create a sqlite database from the calendar file using the script below. The script creates a sqlite table called birthdays, loopS through the birthday events in the calendar file and insert them into the birthdays table.

# process_calendar.py
from icalendar import Calendar
from collections import namedtuple
from datetime import date, timedelta
import sqlite3

birth_day = namedtuple('BD', ['name', 'month', 'day'])

def read_calendar():
    with open('cal.ics', 'rb') as f:
        calics = Calendar.from_ical(f.read())
        for component in calics.walk(name='VEVENT'):
            name = component.get('SUMMARY').replace("'s birthday", "")
            birth_date = component.get('DTSTART').dt
            # print(name, birth_date.strftime("%b %d"))
            yield birth_day(name=name,
                            month=str.lower(birth_date.strftime("%b")),
                            day=birth_date.day)


def persist_data():
    connection = sqlite3.connect('birthdays.db')
    cursor = connection.cursor()
    cursor.execute(
        '''CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS birthdays
        (id INTEGER NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
        name INTEGER NOT NULL,
        month TEXT NOT NULL,
        day INTEGER NOT NULL)''')
    for item in read_calendar():
        cursor.execute('''INSERT INTO birthdays VALUES (NULL,?,?,?)''',
                       (item.name, item.month, item.day))
    connection.commit()
    connection.close()


if __name__ == '__main__':
    persist_data()

The script outputs a file, birthdays.db, which is essentially the birthday data in a sqlite database.

Next, let's write a script that given a month and a day, returns the names of your friends whose birthdays are on the specified date.

# birthdays.py
from datetime import date, timedelta
import sqlite3

def fetch_birthday_friends_by_date(month, day):
    connection = sqlite3.connect('birthdays.db')
    c = connection.cursor()
    f_list = []
    for row in c.execute('''SELECT DISTINCT name FROM birthdays
							WHERE month=? and day=?''',
                         (month, day,)):
        f_list.append(row[0])
    connection.close()
    return "{} {}".format(month, day), f_list

# app.py
import os
from datetime import date
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from twilio.rest import Client
import birthdays as bdays

app = Flask(__name__)

def send_sms(msg, from_='+166...', to='+233...'):
    # Your Account Sid and Auth Token from twilio.com/console
    account_sid = ''
    auth_token = ''
    client = Client(account_sid, auth_token)
    message = client.messages.create(body=msg, from_=from_, to=to)
    print(message.sid)

@app.route('/')
def index():
    return "<h1>Hello Containerizers!!</h1>"

@app.route('/birthday_friends', defaults={'month': None, 'day': None})
@app.route('/birthday_friends/<month>-<int:day>')
def get_birthday_friends(month, day):
    if not month or not day:
        now = date.today()
        month = str.lower(now.strftime("%b"))
        day = now.day
    birthdate, f_list = bdays.fetch_birthday_friends_by_date(month, day)
    bday_friends = {}
    bday_friends['date'], bday_friends['names'] = birthdate, []
    if f_list:
        bday_friends['names'] = f_list
        if request.args.get('notify') == 'true':
            send_sms(bday_friends)
return jsonify(bday_friends)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(host="0.0.0.0", port=int(os.environ.get('PORT', 8080)), debug=True)

7. Build and run the container image

Now, let's get to the actual docker image building. We are packaging the birthday app in a container image.

To build a container image, we have to tell Docker how to do step by step. The Dockerfile is used for that purpose. Inside of the directory that contains the birthday app, we create a file called Dockerfile that contains the following instructions:

FROM python:3.7-alpine
RUN pip install --upgrade pip
WORKDIR /app
COPY requirements.txt ./
RUN pip install --no-cache-dir --requirement requirements.txt
RUN pip install Flask gunicorn
COPY birthdays.db birthdays.py app.py ./
CMD exec gunicorn --bind :$PORT --workers 1 --threads 8 app:app
# CMD python app.py

Once the Dockerfile is right and ready, we can now build the container image. We will build it using docker build command and run it locally using docker run command. Then we will use Cloud Build to do the same thing, except we won't run the container locally, we will push it to Container Registry and deploy it to Cloud Run.

7.1. Build and run locally

Before we proceed, make sure you have docker installed. If you are not certain, run docker version command to check it. The output looks something like this

The context is the content of the directory that contains the files (code) of your app. According to the Dockerfile reference, the context can be a Git repository location or a directory on your local filesystem. In our case here, we use the current directory as the context.

1docker build --tag bdays-reminder:0.1 .

We use --tag flag to give a name to our container image and tag it. The tag is placed after : after the name, and it's optional. The output of the docker build command above looks like this:

We can run docker ps or docker container ls to display the list of containers that are spun up. Sometimes the output of this command is cumbersome. We can choose what information to display.

To stop a running container, we use docker stop command with the container ID; for example in this case, the container ID is db3382796905. So to stop it, we run 

1docker stop db3382796905

Run docker ps to make sure that the container has been effectively stopped.

7.2. Tell Cloud Build to do everything

In this section, we are going to use Cloud Build to build and tag a Docker image, push the to Google Container Registry and deploy it to Cloud Run. Cloud Build is a Google's service that offers CI/CD fonctionalities that cover all the software development stages in cloud environments as well as on premises environments. Essentially you submit the build, test and deployment processes to Cloud Build by providing the build steps in a configuration file. The builds run on the GCP and you can use high-CPU VMs to further increase the build speed.

We will be using Cloud SDK gcloud command-line tool If you haven't installed it yet, go ahead and install it. If you have already installed it, run gcloud components update to have the latest available version.

Run this command to log in to GCP

1gcloud auth login

Set the project that you will be working with. Replace PROJECT_ID by the actual project ID.

1gcloud config set project PROJECT_ID

Export the project ID as the environment variable $GCLOUD_PROJECT; it will save us from the mechanical task of typing and typos.

1export GCLOUD_PROJECT=`(gcloud config get-value project)`

You can list all the projects you have access to with the current account by running gcloud projects list.

Let's also export the project number, because we are going to use it multiple times.

1export PROJECT_NUMBER=`(gcloud projects describe $GCLOUD_PROJECT --format="value(projectNumber)")`

Enable APIs

To build container images on the GCP and deploy them to Cloud Run, we have to enable the Resource Manager API, Cloud Build API, the Container Registry API and Cloud Run API:

1gcloud services enable cloudbuild.googleapis.com \
2    containerregistry.googleapis.com \
3    cloudresourcemanager.googleapis.com \
4    run.googleapis.com

Build and run

Now let's build a docker image and push it to Container Registry with the command below. 

1gcloud builds submit --tag gcr.io/$GCLOUD_PROJECT/bdays-reminder:0.1

Let's deploy the container image we just built to Cloud Run 

1gcloud beta run deploy bdays-reminder-service-m \
2   --image gcr.io/$GCLOUD_PROJECT/bdays-reminder:0.1 \
3   --region us-central1 --platform managed --memory 128Mi \
4   --timeout 60 --allow-unauthenticated

Now, you are probably thinking, didn't you write "Tell Cloud Build to do everything", but Cloud Build didn't actually do everything, we just manually deployed a container image to Cloud Run. You are right. We tell Cloud Build to do everything in the section below.

Define the build steps in a config file

Instead of typing the build and running commands one after the other, we can use Cloud Build configuration file to do it at once. In the same directory that contains our app code and the Dockerfile, let's create a file named cloudbuild.yaml. This file will contain instructions that tell Cloud Build to build, push and run our container image. The contents of the build config file is as follow:

 1
 2
 3

 5

steps:
# Build the container image
- name: 'gcr.io/cloud-builders/docker'
  args: ['build', '-t', 'gcr.io/$PROJECT_ID/bdays-reminder:0.2', '.']
# Push the container image to Container Registry
- name: 'gcr.io/cloud-builders/docker'
  args: ['push', 'gcr.io/$PROJECT_ID/bdays-reminder:0.2']
# Deploy container image to Cloud Run
- name: 'gcr.io/cloud-builders/gcloud'
  args: ['beta', 'run', 'deploy', 'bdays-reminder-service-a', '--image', 'gcr.io/$PROJECT_ID/bdays-reminder:0.2', '--region', 'us-central1', '--memory', '128Mi', '--timeout', '60', '--platform', 'managed', '--allow-unauthenticated']
images: ['gcr.io/$PROJECT_ID/bdays-reminder:0.2']

Cloud Build will substitute $PROJECT_ID with the actual project ID set in the active Cloud SDK configuration (gcloud config set project PROJECT_ID). In lines 3-4, Cloud build builds a docker image named and tagged gcr.io/$PROJECT_ID/bdays-reminder:0.2. In lines 6-7, the image is pushed to Container Registry. In lines 9-10, the image built in previous steps is deployed to Cloud Run.

IAM permissions

Before we start the build, let's talk (think) about IAM permissions.

If we were using Cloud Console, we wouldn't have any problem with the build and deployment. In fact when we previously ran gcloud builds and gcloud beta run deploy commands we didn't worry about permissions. Why? Because as project owner, you have all the permissions to do everything to your project including screwing everything up. But since we are going to use Cloud Build to deploy our container image to Cloud Run, Cloud Build service account has to be granted Cloud Run Admin role, else it can't deploy to Cloud Run. The same thing apply to other GCP services. For Cloud Build to interact with other GCP services, we have to grant Cloud Build service account the necessary roles so it has the permission to perform the tasks.

With the command below, we are adding an IAM policy binding for the role of roles/run.admin to the Cloud Build service account which is $PROJECT_NUMBER@cloudbuild.gserviceaccount.com. Remember that we exported the actual project number as the env var $PROJECT_NUMBER.

1gcloud projects add-iam-policy-binding $GCLOUD_PROJECT \
2      --member="serviceAccount:$PROJECT_NUMBER@cloudbuild.gserviceaccount.com" \
3      --role='roles/run.admin'

We have to pay attention to another thing which is that a service account is also a resource besides being an identity. So as a GCP resource, they have IAM policies. A service account has to have the Service Account user role to be able to run operations as a service account 🤯. In our case, we have to grant the Service Account User role (roles/iam.serviceAccountUser) for Cloud Run service account to the Cloud Build service account. We will grant it at the service account level, not at the project level. Wait whaaa? :confused:.

Now let's run the command that will grant the service account user role to the service account. We know the Cloud Build service account identifier. But what about Cloud Run's? Cloud Run uses the Compute Engine default service account by default ($PROJECT_NUMBER-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com). However it's not recommended to work with this default setup, because the Compute Engine default service account have read and write access to all resources in your GCP project. That's too much power. Good IAM policies should always follow the principle of least privilege. But let's go with the default for now.

1gcloud iam service-accounts add-iam-policy-binding \
2	$PROJECT_NUMBER-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com \
3	--member="serviceAccount:$PROJECT_NUMBER@cloudbuild.gserviceaccount.com" \
4	--role='roles/iam.serviceAccountUser'

If it worked, the output would look like this.

:tired_face: ok ok, now the actual build

Now we are all set to start the build by running the command below from the directory containing the Dockerfile and the cloudbuild.yaml file. Run the magic command below:

1gcloud builds submit

After successful completion, you will see SUCCESS at the end of the output and a message like this:

1Service [bdays-reminder-service] revision [bdays-reminder-service-0001]
2has been deployed and is serving 100 percent of traffic at
3https://bdays-reminder-service-[hash].a.run.app

To obtain the service URL, run the following command: 

1SERVICE_URL=$(gcloud beta run services describe pdf-converter --platform managed --region us-central1 --format="value(status.url)")

Make a GET request to your new service: 

1curl $SERVICE_URL

Run this command to list your Cloud Run services.

1gcloud beta run services list --platform=managed

8. Create a con job to invoke the Cloud Run service

We just need to to create a job to periodically call the HTTP endpoint of the service we just deployed. Get the URL and replace it in the commands below:

1gcloud scheduler jobs create http bday-reminder-job \
2   --schedule="0 17 * * *" \
3   --uri="YOUR_URL/birthday_friends&notify=true" \
4   --http-method=GET

When we were deploying the image to Cloud Run, we used the --allow-unauthenticated flag, which makes Cloud Run services plublic, accessible to anybody who knows the HTTP endpoints. If we wanted to protect it we'd have used the --no-allow-unauthenticated flag instead. And in that case, to invoke the secured endpoint using Cloud Scheduler, we'd have to pass the authentication token to the header of the request like in the command below:

1gcloud scheduler jobs create http bday-reminder-job  \
2   --schedule="0 17 * * *"  \
3   --uri="$SERVICE_URL/birthday_friends&notify=true"  \
4   --http-method=GET \
5   --time-zone="Africa/Accra" \
6   --headers="{'Authorization'='Bearer `(gcloud auth print-identity-token)`'}"

And that's it. Thanks for reading :raised_hands:. À la prochaine

item.title: Deploy to Cloud Functions, Schedule invocations Using Cloud Scheduler
item.description:
TL;DR: This post is about Scheduling Firebase Cloud Functions with Cloud Scheduler. Precisely we use Cloud Functions to deploy a birthday reminder app and use Cloud Scheduler to invoke the app.

A couple of weeks ago, I stumbled upon a repo on GitHub, it's a Flask app that uses Twilio to send SMS notifications about your friends' upcoming birthdays. It has a script that can be run as a background job using schedule, a lighweight python job scheduing library, to check once a day for birthdays and it sends out an SMS to your configured phone number if there is a birthday that day.

It's an interesting idea especially if you want to keep up with your friends' birthdays and don't want to use Facebook for it. Unless you can (or want to?) memorize all of them or laboriously save them in your contacts, you probably need to have a mechanism to help you remember them. Know that you may memorize them and still forget to remember them when the actual days come.

Facebook already has all of your friends' birthdays data, at least of those who decided to share them. How to export them is covered here.

This birthday app has a front-end with a page that displays birthdays by month, and other pages. But let's assumed we just have a backend that checks for birthdays and sends out SMS notifications, there is no front-end, at least not a 'meaningful' one.

The question we then have to ask ourselves is where should we deploy and run our minimal birthday reminder app? We can run it on our laptop; but what if you don't have internet connection to call the Twilio's API? What if you don't turn on your laptop? Ok, so we should deploy it on a remote server. It should be low-cost, preferably free. And we don't want to have to manage it (restarting the job for example). To recap, we want a service that is

  • fully-managed
  • low-cost/cost-effective (I really mean free, to be honest)
  • reliable

Google Cloud Functions looks perfect for this.

1. What is Google Cloud Functions?

Google Cloud Functions is a lightweight, event-based, asynchronous compute solution that allows you to create small, single-purpose functions that respond to cloud events without the need to manage a server or a runtime environment.

Essentially what this means is that you write a function that will be called upon an HTTP request or other events happening in Google Cloud (a message being published, a file being uploaded to or deleted from cloud storage, etc.), deploy it to Google Cloud and you relax.

Google Cloud Functions is fully-managed, you don't have to grapple with any management overhead. It's free for the first 2 million invocations per month. Only when you used up the free tier that you are billed for subsequent invocations. In our case, it's clear that we won't be paying anything; unless we screw up the job scheduler. Google Cloud Functions is highly available. If the service stops working because of whatever reason, the problem will be handled without your intervention and the service will come back up.

2. The code

I repurposed the initial birthday app for Cloud Functions:

import os
from icalendar import Calendar
from collections import namedtuple
from datetime import date
from twilio.rest import Client
from google.cloud import storage

# Access cloud storage bucket and download the Calendar
BUCKET_NAME = os.environ.get('CLOUD_STORAGE_BUCKET')
storage_client = storage.Client()
bucket = storage_client.get_bucket(BUCKET_NAME)
blob = bucket.get_blob('bday-reminder/cal.ics')
blob.download_to_filename('/tmp/cal.ics')

birth_day = namedtuple('BD', ['name', 'month', 'day'])


def read_calendar():
    ''' Reads the calendar file and generates
    a tuple with name and birthday's month and
    date for each entry in the calendar file '''
    with open('/tmp/cal.ics', 'rb') as f:
        calics = Calendar.from_ical(f.read())
        for component in calics.walk(name='VEVENT'):
            name = component.get('SUMMARY').replace("'s birthday", "")
            birth_date = component.get('DTSTART').dt
            yield birth_day(name=name,
                            month=birth_date.month,
                            day=birth_date.day)


# Your Account Sid and Auth Token from twilio.com/console

def notify(request):
    ''' HTTP Cloud Function
    Checks if today is the birthday of a friend.
    If yes, send out a message '''
    today = date.today()
    bday_names = ''
    for bday in read_calendar():
        if bday.month == today.month and bday.day == today.day:
            bday_names += '\n{}'.format(bday.name)
    msg = '{}{}'.format(today, bday_names)
    if bday_names:
        send_sms(msg)
    return '<br>'.join(msg.splitlines())

4. Let's deploy the app to Google Cloud Functions

Let's deploy our birthday app to Google Cloud Functions using Cloud Console. We will first create a new project. Then we create a cloud storage bucket and upload the calendar file to that bucket. Next, we create a cloud function and subsequently create a job that will call the function on a recurring schedule. I assume that you have a Google Cloud account

a. Navigate to Google Cloud Console and click CREATE to create a new project

b. Enter the project's name and click CREATE

c. Click on Select a project on the app bar and select the project you just created

d. Click on the menu button (amburger icon) and click on Storage to Create a bucket. Then click Create bucket

e. Enter a name for the bucket and click CREATE. Bucket names have to be globally unique

Take note of the bucket name, you will need it in the next steps.

f. Upload the calendar file to the bucket

g. Move the calendar file inside of a folder that can be created by clicking on Create folder. Name the folder bday-reminder

h. Click on the menu button and click on Cloud Functions. Then click Create function

If the Cloud Functions API is not enabled, instead of a button Create function, you would see Enable API. Click on it to enable Cloud Functions and navigate back to the Cloud Functions console to finally create a function.

i. Fill out the form with the relevant information and click Create to deploy your function

  • Function name: bday-reminder
